p: The epidemic’s epicenter has shifted from the coastal urban centers to the Southern United States [ 5]: home to approximately 50% of persons who are newly diagnosed, living, or dying with HIV; where the HIV knowledge and health of PWH is below the national average; and where various regional disparities are rampant, driven by pervasive economic, cultural, social, structural, and geopolitical factors [ 7]. In this study, we examine the HIV epidemic and control efforts in Texas, the second largest and second most populous US state, against a backdrop of the epidemic’s history in Houston, its largest city.
